By year end, production volumes reached a capability exit rate of 3,544 boepd, up 4% from the 3,414 boepd capability exit level in 2005.     GEOCAN committed to a more balanced commodity mix than it had a year ago, aiming for one third heavy oil, one third light/medium oil, and one third natural gas. At year end, the company's mix moved further in this direction with production distributed 45% to heavy oil (2005: 56%), 35% to natural gas (2005: 25%), and 20% to light/medium oil (2005: 19%). Management believes a balance of all three commodities allows the company to focus on exploration and development projects that are consistent with each commodity's price cycle.        Lloydminster discovery     GEOCAN discovered a significant heavy oil pool near Lloydminster that independent third party engineers DeGolyer and MacNaughton Canada Limited have estimated at 24.8 million barrels of probable reserves.     The pool, which was delineated with five vertical wells in 2006, is concentrated in less than one section of land, making development relatively straight forward. The reservoir is 3D seismically defined. It displays good characteristics for a SAGD program, and is in an area well served by pipelines and other infrastructure. The company holds 100% working interest in the discovery.     A pilot phase will likely be initiated to validate the geologic model and streamline any technical issues before proceeding to a full-scale enhanced recovery scheme. This pilot project would include two to three horizontal well pairs with surface facilities to handle the associated production volumes. This phase is expected to cost approximately $40 million. Preliminary estimates identifying potentially up to 15 well pairs could be necessary to fully develop the reserves in place. The full phase development including the initial pilot is anticipated to cost $200 million.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:50 ET (04:50 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Exchange-Traded Funds: Digging For Solid Returns
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Exchange-traded funds are starting to make a big splash in the fixed-income markets, as the popular investment vehicles -- to date, used largely to bundle equities, not bonds -- continue to innovate, mutate and proliferate.   Given the stock market's weakness -- the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down about 450 points since hitting a record close of 12,786.64 on Feb. 20 -- investors might want to take a look at these new products as tools for diversifying and adding stability to their investment portfolios. Bonds tend to be safer bets than stocks, although their returns are often lower.   Exchange-traded funds track indexes, and they trade on stock exchanges. They have low net-expense ratios -- as little as 0.07% for stock ETFs -- and they are passively managed against an index. The first ETF was launched in 1993. Now, there are more than 300 ETFs tied to stock indexes.   But the first exchange-traded funds to follow a bond index were introduced by Barclays Global Investors in 2002: the iShares iBoxx Investment Grade Corporate Bond Fund (ticker: LQD), the iShares Lehman 1-3 Year Treasury Bonds (SHY), the iShares Lehman 20+ year Treasury Bond (TLT) and the iShares Lehman 7-10 Year Treasury (IEF). Each had a net expense ratio in 2006 of 0.15% according to Morningstar.   After introducing two more exchange-traded funds tied to a bond index in 2003, Barclays is now further ramping up supply. The banking firm launched eight bond ETFs in January of this year and, in March, it rolled out the first index tied to mortgage-backed securities: the iShares MBS Fixed-Rate Bond (MBB).   Mortgage-backed securities are bonds secured by home loans. The fund, which has an expense ratio of 0.25%, went public despite the meltdown in the subprime mortgage market, which has roiled financial markets.   For this particular class of bonds, "The timing couldn't be worse," says Jeff Buetow, chief investment officer for XTF, an asset-management firm that builds and manages portfolios of ETFs. He passed on investing in the mortgage ETF, but he points out that prime mortgages are still popular because of the collateral, as opposed to riskier subprime loans, typically granted to home buyers with little financial security.   ETF launches are anything but easy to time. "The process for filing and launch [of an ETF] takes time," says Matthew Tucker, head of the investment-solutions group at Barclay's Global Investors And the approval process at the Securities and Exchange Commission marches to its own drummer.   So far, the funds launched have drawn a mix of retail buy-and-hold purchasers and institutions. "We're very happy with the liquidity," Tucker says.   Rather than buying a Treasury bill directly from the government, Mom and Pop now can invest in funds that are low-cost, tradable and protective of the principal.   ETFs are generally cheaper than regular mutual funds, and have tax advantages. But in exchange for those benefits, investors give up an opportunity to have their money minded by mutual-fund portfolio managers whose job it is to find undervalued assets and outperform indexes.   "It's always appropriate to include exposure to bonds" in a diversified investment portfolio, says Sonya Morris, senior mutual-fund analyst at Morningstar. "A good, solid diversified ETF has a good shot at doing well over the long term," she says.   Of course, bonds do best in a falling-interest-rate environment. Currently, economists are divided as to whether the economy is slowing enough for the Federal Reserve to begin cutting rates, or whether inflation is too much of a worry for the Fed to ignore.   The Fed's policymakers, at their most recent meeting in March, said that inflation pressures, rather than worries about slowing growth in the U.S. economy, were their "predominant" concern.   And Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke, in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress last week, reaffirmed this stance, saying that "we have not shifted away from an inflation bias,"" because inflation is, in his words, "uncomfortably high."" That adds more evidence to support the theory that the Fed won't be cutting rates anytime soon, despite recent signs of subpar economic growth.   Still, the futures market is betting on lower rates ahead. The June Eurodollar contract priced in a 68% chance for a rate cut in the second quarter after last week's U.S. durable-goods report showed a smaller-than-expected increase in February and a downward revision of already-weak January numbers. That compared with a 56% chance before the report was released. However, some see the Fed standing pat, as it has since it paused in mid-2006 in the wake of 17 increases in a row.   "Rates may drop over the next 12 to 24 months, but not appreciably," says Lou Stanasolovich, chief executive officer of Legend Financial Advisors in Pittsburgh, who has loaded up with syndicated bank loans and floating-rate notes for interest-rate protection. The firm, he says, hasn't been a big fan of fixed-rate bonds for 3 1/2 years, due to their historically low yields.   The appetite for yield has Barclays and Valley Forge, Pa.-based Vanguard, the mutual-fund giant, looking to offer exchange-traded funds tied to risky junk bonds later this year.   The high-yield market has been a stellar performer the past few years, due in part to negligible corporate-default rates. However, risk premiums are very narrow; too narrow, say some who follow the market -- including Barron's.   Vanguard also has four fixed-income ETFs in the registration pipeline at the SEC that are expected launch this month: Vanguard Total Bond ETF (BND), Vanguard Short-Term Bond ETF (BSV), Vanguard Intermediate-Term Bond ETF (BIV) and Vanguard Long-Term Bond ETF (BLV).   The new Vanguard ETFs will be the lowest-cost and most broadly diversified available, according to Morningstar, with an expense ratio of 0.11%.   Bear Stearns is also looking to bond with investors. It recently filed to offer a Current Yield Fund, an ETF with a twist: It would be an exchange-traded-fundlike investment that would be actively managed -- in other words, a portfolio manager will pick the holdings, rather than letting the fund mirror an index.   Its fate before the SEC, however, is uncertain, because while a number of companies have tried to get approval for them, the SEC has so far failed to clear an actively managed exchange-traded fund.   Meanwhile, although Vanguard will compete with lower expense ratios, Barclays' Tucker says his firm doesn't fear the competition: Barclays' goal is "not to be the lowest-cost provider for every product," but to create "an investment tool kit to manage asset allocation."   The U.K.-based bank has clearly been a leader in the exchange-traded fund arena. Among other things, it pioneered exchange-traded notes, which, like their equity ETF cousins, also track indexes and trade on stock exchanges.   But ETNs also have bondlike characteristics. As senior unsecured-debt securities with 30-year maturities, they reflect the risks of the issuer's credit.   Late last year, Barclays launched the iPath MSCI India Index Exchange-Traded Note (INP), based on the Morgan Stanley Capital International India Total Return Index. That index includes India's 68 largest companies by market capitalization which are listed on the National Stock Exchange of India. It's the first exchange-traded security to play on an emerging market.   Barclays also last year launched three notes tied directly to the prices of commodities -- the Dow Jones-AIG Commodity Index Total Return ETN (DJP), the GSCI Total Return Index ETN (GSP) and the Goldman Sachs Crude Oil Total Return Index ETN (OIL). (Dow Jones is the publisher of Barron's.) More are in the works.   In all, Barclays has nearly 100 equity exchange-traded funds, and will continue its expansion into fixed income, although with "not as many funds" in bonds as in equities, says Tucker. "There's a lot of room for growth. There's room for competition," he observes, adding that the rise of rivals "highlights the benefits" of the investment vehicles.   XTF's Buetow anticipates that fixed-income "buckets" of bonds tied to an index will eventually be refined according to maturity and credit rating.   "You'll see high-yield in the next foray, and you might even see some derivatives-based" exchange-traded funds, he predicts. "Maybe some foreign debt . . . and I do see [debt from] emerging markets," says Buetow.   Yes, bond ETFs have shown "glacial growth" compared with their equity cousins, says Morningstar's Morris. That's because they offer lower returns. But they also provide "lower risk and volatility," attractive qualities for an asset, she adds.   Given the turbulence in equity markets right now, and the uncertain economic outlook, bonds start looking better and better. That's why Treasuries, in particular, are called safe havens. And the new bond ETFs may be one of the handiest ways to get a little shelter from the storm.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Marseille Port Workers End 18-Day Strike
Story: MARSEILLE, France (AP)--Workers in the southern port of Marseille agreed Saturday to return to work after an 18-day strike that had tangled oil supplies to refineries around Europe.   A total of 59 tankers were stranded outside the Fos-sur-Mer oil and gas terminal Saturday due to the strike, which began March 13 because of a dispute over who should be authorized to discharge gas tankers - port employees or employees of gas giant Gaz de France.   After protracted negotiations, a preliminary deal was signed Friday night between the CGT union, the port management and French gas giant Gaz de France.   Workers approved the deal on Saturday, and CGT official Pascal Galeote said work could resume in the afternoon.   Under the deal, GDF workers will unload the gas under the supervision of port agents, Galeote said. He said the aim was to reach a balance between private sector and public sector jobs at the port.   "We have managed to advance things in a positive way, but it's not all over yet," he said.   The terminal is part of Marseille's extensive port activities and feeds six refineries in France, Germany and Switzerland with a combined capacity of 1 million barrels a day.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 06:57 ET (10:57 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Deutsche Telekom Shortlists 3 Cos For Ya.com Sale-Report
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--Deutsche Telekom AG's (DT) has shortlisted three companies for the sale of its Spanish broadband provider Ya.com, Expansion reports Saturday without citing sources.   The German company has given detailed information about Ya.com to Vodafone Group PLC (VOD), Jazztel PLC (JAZ.MC) and France Telecom SA's (FTE) mobile operator Orange so that the companies can make bids for the internet provider, the paper reported.   On Monday, the binding-offer period will begin and the three companies will be asked to make a down payment if they plan to bid.   The sales process is being managed by JP Morgan, the paper added.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.expansion.com   -Madrid Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; (34) 628 278 718     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 01:56 ET (05:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Bracing For Trouble
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview with   Larry Jeddeloh   Founder and Chief Investment Officer   TIS Group     There are few daily e-mails we look forward to as much as the Market Intelligence Report from Minneapolis-based TIS Group, named for The Institutional Strategist, an independent-research service founded by Larry Jeddeloh in 1995. Timely and tuned in to global markets, TIS presents clients with thought-provoking analyses and potentially profitable investment opportunities. Jeddeloh, a former chief investment strategist at Union Bank of Switzerland and onetime director of equity research at the Leuthold Group, also manages about $100 million in private accounts. His latest prognostication: a 15% to 20% drop in the U.S. stock market this year.     Barron's: What are your concerns about the U.S. market?   Jeddeloh: I often like to start with a conclusion. We've been telling clients that at some point this year, we will have a sharp down move in equity markets. It is likely to happen somewhere from May through October, and it could be a drop of anywhere from 15% to 20%, which is too much to ignore from an asset-allocation standpoint or from any standpoint. If I'm on the right track and we get a 15% to 20% decline in the indexes in absolute terms, everything's going down: big-caps, small-caps, you name it.     Q: What we saw in February and early March was just   a precursor?   A: That was a bell ringing; that was the warning shot. There are a couple of factors unfolding that lead us down this path. The biggest concern is U.S. credit. We also have been long-standing bulls on energy, and what is unfolding in the Middle East is a second concern. Third, central banks, not just in the U.S. but overseas, have been warning the markets will go on raising rates. It is pretty clear the European Central Bank will go on raising rates. The Bank of Japan intends to go on raising rates. The Bank of England has warned about raising rates in response to sharp movements in asset prices and how that might feed inflation. And the chairman of our Federal Reserve, Ben Bernanke, from time to time has warned about the upside risk to inflation.   Yet during the selloff in stocks some weeks ago, it was interesting that, almost immediately, market commentators posed the question of whether the Fed will cut rates. It was almost as if there was no tolerance for downside in stocks. They chased down William Poole, the St. Louis Fed chairman, in Santiago, Chile, and in an interview on March 2, he said "At this point, there seems to be no pressing need for any immediate action."   The Fed has to reassert some semblance of moral hazard back into the system. When we do get the next round of stress in the capital markets, the Fed may move slower than the market expects. There won't be an immediate bailout, and they'll allow the private sector to clean it up.     Q: What is your view of the subprime mess? Contained or contagion?   A: I'm getting a lot of pushback from clients, and I'm reading Wall Street reports that make the argument that the subprime problem is going to be contained. Even Bernanke has said something to this effect. Let me tell you a brief story to explain why I think this is wrong.   I used to help people who got in financial trouble get themselves out through a church I'm affiliated with. They would come in and show me their balance sheets and income statements and how much debt they had. We would take a look at how to pay it off. I never saw one time where the person didn't try to save their house. They will always try to make a payment on the house. They'll let the credit card go. They'll let the auto loan, the loan from a relative or a business credit go. But they will try and hang on to their home.   So if you have record highs in delinquencies on home loans, I suspect they are already starting to miss their repayments on student loans, credit cards, gas cards and auto loans. Auto loans are the big concern, because if there was anything easier to buy than real estate in the last five or six years, it was a car.     Q: Would you say a recession is in the works?   A: I'm not prepared to say yet we'll have a recession in the U.S., but the economy will be slower this year than the 2.6% growth the consensus expects. When the economy begins to slow, people will trace it back to what we have been talking about -- problems in the credit system. Suddenly, credit standards start to tighten, and the tighter they become the lower the demand for credit. Then the Fed has to start cutting rates.     Q: Will they cut if inflation remains a threat?   A: That's the dilemma. And it is not just inflation. The other concern the Fed must have is China. I consider the U.S. and China as a single currency bloc. The dollar and the dollar-yuan rate are moving in a very slow tango. The U.S. is asking China to gradually move its currency up. To do that, the U.S. and China have to cooperate on monetary policy. The level of cooperation between U.S. authorities and the Chinese is probably deepening, and that's a good thing. The Chinese, who own hundreds of billions of dollars of U.S. Treasuries, probably have told the U.S. they need a certain rate of return, and they are probably not in favor of a dollar decline. That means higher rates, even though that might contradict what the U.S. economy may need right now.     Q: If the market corrects as much as you say, what is the impact on global markets?   A: If a decline in stocks occurs in the U.S., it will happen in Europe. If they get it in Europe, it will happen in the emerging markets. Another argument being made is that there are places to hide when this type of correction comes. I don't think that's right, either. You are going to see all correlations go to one. Once you get into a steep decline, not a 3%, 4%, 5% garden-variety decline but something deeper, liquidity becomes the issue. Even though smaller markets have more flows than they did five or 10 years ago, they have higher beta. When people start to reduce risk, that's what they'll sell.     The focus lately is on too much liquidity sloshing around, not too little. This could be quite a jolt.   There are some clues in the wind. If you look at the PowerShares Listed Private Equity Portfolio [ticker: PSP] exchange-traded fund, it has broken down. The chart of The Merger Fund [MERFX] has broken down. The charts of Goldman Sachs (GS), Bear Sterns [BSC], Lehman Brothers [LEH], all the firms that are trading subprime credit -- those charts are broken. The chart of the ProShares Ultrashort Dow 30, which trades inversely to the Dow Jones industrials, is moving up.     Q: How are you positioning yourself for a decline the likes of which you see coming?   A: In our global-allocation model, we're 35% in stocks, 45% in cash and 20% in bonds. In the next month or two you could see the markets run again to the upside after this last correction. That's the worst thing that can happen because that will suck everybody in. When that happens, we are going to flip our allocation from cash almost entirely into longer bonds, and we'll reduce our equity component to our minimum of 20% and maybe even go a bit lower. If we get the decline I'm describing later in the year, it might be of short duration. There was a big equity shrink last year, and that's a very powerful dynamic. The private-equity guys may come right after some of the names they are looking for and, bang, the market will go right back up and we'll have a pretty good 2008.     Q: How does energy figure into this picture?   A: There is little geopolitical risk priced into oil. The oil price is set on the supply side, which is more interesting to us. We've had a quiet period for a couple of years and we don't think that is going to last. OPEC supply is falling at the fastest rate in 10 years, and estimates from non-OPEC countries are being cut in half. On the demand side, China is still growing and India is going to increase its demand for oil. Global demand is going to catch up rapidly with the supply, and geopolitical risk is being built into prices again. I do not believe the current U.S. administration will leave the Iran issue for the next president. And Iran has no effective counterstroke other than oil. If they could, they would get the price of oil up as fast and as far as they could. They might try and shut off somebody else's oil. I'd look across the lake at Saudi Arabia and the Emirates.     Q: Is there anything positive here?   A: The bond rallies on economic weakness or a flight-to-safety trade. When we start to get rapid interest-rate cuts and the long end of the bond market responds, we could go through a period of nice outperformance by bonds at the expense of stocks. Another positive, one of the biggest, is emerging in the reallocation of funds going on in China. The People's Bank of China is talking about $150 billion coming out of current reserves and $150 billion in new reserves that will be reallocated. The beneficiaries of those flows will be not just their domestic market. Some of those monies will flow into large-cap equities in the Asia region in Japan or South Korea or Singapore.   One of my bets is you'll see some big Canadian oil company bought by a Chinese company in the next 12 months. The Chinese have been in Africa bidding up prices in some natural-resource areas, as well.     Q: What are some Japanese or Korean equities you like?   A: We are very interested in Japan. There are some great charts in Japan: big-caps like NTT [NTT] NTT DoCoMo [DCM] or KDDI [9433.Japan] and Sony [SNE]. They've come down a long way, and they are building huge bases. If I were the Chinese guy doing the allocating, Japan is the first place I'd go.     Q: Are you invested in commodities?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Less Gain More Pain
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jaqueline Doherty   For the past few years, robust growth in corporate profits and low interest rates have been the twin pillars supporting a bull market in stocks. One of them has just developed fissures.   After 14 quarters of double-digit increases in operating earnings, the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index are expected to post paltry profit gains of 3.8% for the first quarter of 2007 and 4% for the second, according to Thomson Financial. Full-year profits are likely to rise by just 6.7%, the worst showing since 2002.   Some of the blame for these uninspiring numbers rests with consumer-discretionary stocks such as autos and home builders. Back out the first-quarter results expected from Ford Motor (ticker: F) and home builders such as D.R. Horton (DHI) and Toll Brothers (TOL), and S&P earnings over all would rise by 5.4% in the period, according to Thomson Financial.   Sectors such as energy, industrials and technology also face difficult comparisons with the first quarter of 2006, when S&P profits climbed 16%. Add in a weaker economy -- growth in U.S. gross domestic product fell from 5.6% in the first three months of 2006 to 2.5% in the fourth quarter -- and it's easy to see why the Street's expectations are so muted.   "The ripple effects of the downturn in housing are starting to show up in the economy," says Leo Grohowski, chief investment officer at U.S. Trust. In the fourth quarter, a drop in oil prices helped offset the effects of a weaker housing market. But with crude back above $60 a barrel, he says, pressure is building on the consumer.   "The news out of FedEx [FDX] and Motorola [MOT], both somewhat economically sensitive companies, is telling you the environment is more difficult," says Tom McManus, chief investment strategist at Banc of America Securities.   FedEx recently reported a 1.9% drop in net income for its February quarter, as delivery volumes fell faster than the company could cut expenses. Motorola warned it would have a loss in its March quarter due to fewer cellphone sales.   While first-quarter estimates overall could turn out to be too low, McManus says the market might be surprised by the increasing number of companies that guide investors to lower their expectations. That could dash the hopes of analysts, who generally are more optimistic about the year's second half than the first. The growth in operating profits is expected to reaccelerate to 6.8% in the third quarter and 12.5% in the final quarter of '07, though Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at Standard & Poor's, notes there is "a lot of optimism in those [fourth-quarter] numbers."   S&P companies, in the aggregate, are expected to earn $93.62 this year, up from $87.85 in 2006. The index is selling for a reasonable 15 times forward earnings.   Analysts seem to have had a tougher time than usual estimating the latest quarterly results. On Jan. 1 the Street was forecasting profit growth of 8.7%, which had shrunk to 4% by mid-March. The sharp decline occurred in part because preannouncements this year have not been as favorable as in the past. Usually there are two negative earnings announcements for every positive disclosure. The ratio currently is running closer to 3.1 to 1, according to Thomson.   Michael Thompson, director of research at the firm, notes the ratio has risen not because negative announcements have increased, but because positive announcements have decreased. His theory: Companies are being more conservative, opting not to make positive statements as they see the economy slowing.   If history is any guide, earnings estimates will climb as the actual results roll in. That has been the pattern in recent quarters. In the fourth quarter, estimates were in the 8% area before a rash of results pushed the number to 12%. If something similar occurs in the first quarter, actual results will come in closer to 7%, returning earnings growth to its long-term trend. "The number is not going to be as bad as it looks right now," predicts Thompson.   The technology and consumer-staples sectors are likely to provide the biggest lift to first-quarter profits. Both are expected to enjoy earnings growth of 10% to 11%. It's an odd coupling; tech typically is a market favorite in periods of strong economic growth, and consumer-staples companies usually outperform in slow-growth or no-growth periods.   Tech-sector estimates gradually have fallen from 17% at the start of the year. Early announcements in the space have been mixed. Oracle (ORCL) beat estimates for its third quarter, ended Feb. 28, but Motorola, as noted, cut its first-quarter forecast.   Grohowski of U.S. Trust remains wary of the sector, pointing to the slowdown in real nonresidential business fixed-investment spending, specifically spending on equipment and software. "The economy is going to be softer than many believe, and technology isn't an area you want to be in," he says. "Companies seem to be a bit more cautious with their spending plans."   In view of the decline in home prices and the rise in oil prices, investors will be studying closely results from consumer-discretionary companies such as Wal-Mart (WMT), Home Depot (HD) and Best Buy (BBY). Analysts expect the sector's profits to be down 10%, but the headline figure is misleading; consumer-discretionary earnings would be up 8% in the quarter if not for the poor performance of the auto makers and home builders.   "The consumer is doing just fine," Thompson says. "You can't get into a good restaurant on a Saturday night without a reservation, and you can't get a parking spot at the mall. As long as personal income climbs, spending will, too."   The energy sector also is likely to be a drag on S&P earnings, with an expected decline of 3% in first-quarter profits. But that doesn't necessarily mean big trouble in the oil patch; sector earnings soared 36% in the first quarter of 2006, making for an extremely difficult comparison.   What will decelerating earnings growth mean for stock prices? Not everyone is pessimistic. James Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management, notes that 91% of real gross domestic product is growing by 4.3%. Only 9% of the economy is contracting by 10% -- the part that is attracting all the attention.   "There are some nontraditional things that will keep this recovery growing longer and stronger than people expect," says Paulsen, citing rapid growth in the emerging world. China, India and Mexico still have "strikingly strong" economic growth, and that is helping U.S. exports. Inflation is under 3%, the 10-year Treasury bond at a 4.6% yield is not far from historic lows, the dollar is weak and stock earnings multiples continue to fall, even as profits rose in a strong economy.   "In this recovery we never built up confidence," Paulsen adds. "It has been a Chicken Little recovery."   As long as the positive trends continue, he intends to remain with the market leaders of the past few years: small-capitalization stocks, technology, industrials, basic materials and consumer cyclicals. Industrials and basic-materials companies are expected to post 5% to 6% earnings growth in the first quarter.   Given the recent focus in the market and media on the mess in subprime lending, financial-sector results are likely to get a thorough review. The sector is expected to report that earnings grew by 7% in the March quarter, but in view of the blow-out earnings reported by investment banks such as Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Lehman Brothers (LEH), that number could prove conservative. Since their quarters ended in February, however, and much of the subprime fallout occurred in March, second-quarter earnings could prove more illuminating.   After three-and-a-half years of double-digit gains, Corporate America's profit machine arguably is due for some downtime. If the economy continues to expand at a moderate pace, earnings growth should pick up smartly, rendering 4% gains an unpleasant aberration. And if it tanks? On the bright side, comparisons will get a whole lot easier come the first quarter of 2008.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Asian Trader: Flying Execs Help Airlines Take Wing
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Rattaphol Onsanit   Asian airline shares have found a way to increase their lift: Attract business travelers, who are increasingly seen perusing their BlackBerrys or tapping laptop computer keys in the region's bustling airport waiting areas.   Robust Asian corporate earnings bankroll more and more business trips, aiding profitability and share prices at air carriers like Air New Zealand (ticker: AIR.New Zealand), Cathay Pacific (0293.Hong Kong), Qantas (QAN.Australia) and Singapore Airlines (S55.Singapore) that cater to corporate travelers, say analysts. "While it is possible to argue that corporate profits will shortly peak, we note corporate capital expenditure generally lags corporate profitability by around 12 months," UBS said in a recent research piece. Translation: Expansion of travel budgets is expected to continue.   More business jaunts are just one potential boon to the airlines' bottom line. Jet-fuel prices may level off or possibly drop, benefiting those with the proper hedges in place.   And tighter industry seating capacity should help improve operating efficiency. In fact some analysts view Asia as the best of the world's operating environments.   Lehman Brothers, for instance, points out that U.S. carriers continue to add new planes even as the country's economy softens. European companies, meanwhile, may feel the pinch from the larger U.S. fleets. "Although EU airlines are not adding much, the U.S. carriers are diverting planes away from the U.S. domestic [market] onto the Atlantic," J.P. Morgan said in a note.   Asian capacity is tighter thanks mostly to the Airbus consortium's model A380 delivery delays and the airlines' more prudent expansion plans. This results in a higher percentage of seats filled. Qantas, for one, saw its load factor for international flights surge to a historic high of 86.6% in January, about six percentage points above the 10-year average for the month, says Macquarie Research.   Qantas may provide the whole industry with a little lift. If it works out, a private-equity bid to buy Australia's marque airliner could bring more rationality to pricing. "Qantas' LBO (leveraged buyout) is likely to create more sensible competition as new private owners are unlikely to pursue aggressive fare discounting to gain market share," says analyst Chin Lim of Morgan Stanley. The Chinese airlines have been particularly aggressive price-cutters.   Rising Asian currencies against the U.S. dollar also help because major costs, notably fuel, spare parts and aircraft leases, are denominated in dollars. China Eastern (CEA), which has lots of dollar debt, should reap a windfall from the currency's decline, says UBS.   Although predicting oil prices is tricky, some analysts foresee lower jet-fuel costs, which represent more than a third of many airlines' spending. For example, Citigroup expects jet-fuel prices to slide 7% this year to $75 a barrel.   That's not necessarily a positive for all carriers because some have hedged against rising prices or positioned themselves poorly. Fuel costs of Japan's All Nippon Airways (9202.Japan), for example, are likely to rise by 45 billion yen (US$384 million) next fiscal year as a result of its hedging strategy, according to Mitsubishi UFJ Securities. "Even if fuel prices did fall, the company's fuel costs will likely remain high," the brokerage firm said.   Another caveat: Airlines that rely heavily on cargo services can't increase their business-traveler seating so easily. So while they avoid problems caused by the outbreak of regional diseases, air cargo lines can't get the fat premiums that robust corporate travel and tight capacity bring. What's more, the air cargo lines already are contending with cheaper sea-freighter rates. Korean Airlines (003490.Korea), the world's biggest cargo hauler, is one name some analysts recommend avoiding right now.   Analysts said smart marketing and pricing strategies, plus well diversified revenue structures are the keys to outperformance this year. "In our view, the airlines that are experiencing the least capacity growth in home markets face the lowest forecasting risk," UBS said.   Among UBS' picks are Singapore Airlines, which it projects will earn 1.64 Singapore dollars (US$1.08) in 2007, up from S$1.02 in 2006. The shares closed Friday at S$16.60 and UBS has a target of S$22 for them. It also likes Air New Zealand, but the shares closed Friday at 2.34 New Zealand dollars (US$1.67), close to UBS' NZ$2.45 target.   "The Chinese and Korean carriers face the highest risks from a yield perspective as any downside shock would also likely lead to yield degradation," says UBS.   Chinese stocks are also pricey. Merrill notes that Air China's (0753.Hong Kong) shares closed at 5.40 Hong Kong dollars (US$0.69) Friday, which it views as fair value. Merrill expects Air China's 2007 earnings to be near-flat with 2006.   ---   Rattaphol Onsanit is a senior correspondent for Dow Jones Newswires in Bangkok, Thailand.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) The Perils Of Bankrolling Slackers
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   First Marblehead, a specialist in student loans, is an extraordinary company on a number of counts.   Its earnings have stair-stepped to heaven in recent years, rising from $160 million, or $1.59 a share, in the fiscal year ended June 30, 2005, to $236 million, or $2.45 a share in fiscal 2006. More of the same is expected for the fiscal year ending this June and the year thereafter. Consensus forecasts call for fiscal 2007 earnings to jump almost 60% to $3.91 a sharefollowed by $4.41 a share in fiscal 2008.   Moreover, the company (ticker: FMD)boasts operating margins of around 70%. This is in large part because the company merely "facilitates" college and graduate students obtaining loans, rather than making the loans itself. It works with various bank clients like JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC), acting as a classic middleman in structuring the products and handling the paperwork. Marblehead neither services the loans it creates nor puts up its own money.   Yet when First Marblehead then bundles these loans into securities on behalf of its lender clients, the company takes an extraordinary upfront "advisory" fee of as much as 13% of the total value of the loans going into the securitization. This is a huge first bite of the pizza, especially since many of the loans in the securitization trusts won't fully pay off for 20 to 24 years. And the upfront cash goes to Marblehead on a non-recourse basis, meaning the company doesn't have to cover any future losses on the loans.   Not surprisingly, First Marblehead's stock has performed well, at least up until lately. It rose some 150% last year, jumping from $21.90 on a split-adjusted basis to $54.65. The stock has since tailed off some, currently trading at around $45 a share.   There's a good chance that further declines lie ahead. A close look at the loans in First Marblehead's securitizations suggests that defaults are nearing the danger level, as higher interest rates and falling home prices take a toll on families' abilities to make payments. That, in turn, could reduce investors' appetite for the securities and crimp the company's margins.   At the same time, various regulators have been circling around the loosely policed market for private student-loans, First Marblehead's lifeblood. Last year private loans amounted to some $17 billion of the $85 billion in total new student loans; government-backed loans, which First Marblehead doesn't handle, made up the rest.   Sen. Ted Kennedy has proposed legislation that would drastically increase scrutiny of the private student loan industry and thereby lower the cost of the loans. New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo has launched an investigation of various alleged kickbacks private student lenders have extended to U.S. colleges and universities to get on the institutions' preferred lender lists. First Marblehead officials told Barron's that while it hasn't been contacted by Cuomo's office, several of its bank clients have.   For that matter, last year's surge in the stock price wasn't as impressive as it looked. It was in part the result of starting at a depressed level: A minor scandal that erupted in the fall of 2005 had sent the stock skittering below 15. At the time, reports surfaced that company co-founder and then First Marblehead CEO Daniel Meyers had lavished more than $30,000 worth of gifts on a female student-loan executive at Bank of America. The crisis quickly passed, however, when neither Bank of America nor any major bank clients pulled their business from First Marblehead. Meyers, known in the investment community as Jabba the Hutt because of his girth and cantankerous disposition, was forced to step down from his executive post, though he remains a major shareholder of the company.   The stock's recent decline comes as detractors argue, quite plausibly, that the company's results are too good to be sustained, and that its fat profit margins will inevitably invite crippling competition.   Bulls, for their part, insist that First Marblehead should be able to retain its competitive edge and enjoy strong profit growth in the years ahead. Tom Brown, a former top-ranked bank-security analyst who now runs the Second Curve Capital hedge fund, is a major holder of the stock and has been aboard in size since before the 2005 swoon. He sees burgeoning cash flows for the company in the 2008-2010 period, in part because of future "residual income" that will be thrown off by securitizations the company has already issued.   Brown is known for his high-risk bets in the financial arena. His holdings in several subprime-mortgage lenders have cost him dearly this year, but his fund was up nearly 55% last year. He claims that First Marblehead will be yet another of his successful contrarian plays, like his forays in 2003 into auto-finance company AmeriCredit (ACF) and credit-card purveyor Capital One (COF) when both companies were in the dumps.   John Barnett, an investment analyst at Alex Brown Investment Management, a major holder of First Marblehead, is encouraged by the company's growth prospects in light of the pell-mell rise in college tuitions. Private student loans are becoming an evermore important necessity with annual caps on government loans per student sitting at about $4,500 a year depending on the student's class level.   First Marblehead also benefits from a crucial competitive advantage over its peers, according to Barnett. It is the only private-loan securitizer allowed by the rating agencies not only to take cash payments out at issuance of the securitization but to also undercollateralize the trusts set up for the securitizations. Simply put, the trust purchases student loans worth less than it borrows for the purchases. Eventually the shortfall is made up -- usually some seven to eight years into the life of the trust -- as a result of the excess spread of four to five full percentage points between the rates the students pay on their loans and the interest rates the trust pays its investors.   This edge, or what Barnett insists is a barrier to entry enjoyed by First Marblehead, arises from a database First Marblehead purchased in 2001 that now includes some 22 years of private student-loan performance. The company has persuaded the rating agencies that by using this history to precisely model loan risk in its pricing, First Marblehead merits the preferential treatment its securitizations are accorded: The bulk of the deals are rated triple-A.   While there may be some merit to such contentions, certain doubts obtrude. For one thing, actual loan performance seems wanting when one looks into the belly of the beast to see how recent securitizations have actually performed. Barron's concentrated its attention on eight securitizations of some $5.3 billion in First Marblehead student loans done between fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2006. Newer securitizations such as a $1.1 billion offering issued three weeks ago are too new to reveal much.   The company's model calls for gross cumulative defaults in any securitization to not exceed peak levels of just above 9% before recoveries from dead-beat students or their parents (about 80% of First Marblehead loans are co-signed by parents) kick in eventually to push the net default rate down to around 5%. These behavior assumptions are baked into all the First Marblehead's securitizations and are crucial to the pampered treatment the company receives from the rating agencies.   First Marblehead officials declined to share with Barron's its internal estimates based on past experience of the time cycle of defaults and recoveries. This, after all, is part of the company's secret sauce. But we were told that all the securitizations in question were performing as the company and the rating agencies expected and therefore no change in assumptions was in order.   One wonders, however. Take its securitization 2004-1 (the first securitization of 2004 issued in June) in which $584 million in loans were securitized. Some 72% of those loans are now in repayment -- students begin repayment on their loans only six months after they graduate or drop out of school. Yet already 6.41% of the whole portfolio has defaulted, or 8.9% of the actual loans in repayment.   The latter number is dangerously near the projected peak for defaults in such securitizations, 9.2%. Moreover under industry norms, default rates keep rising until about the eight-year mark of many securitizations, when recoveries begin to drive the default curve lower. The rate easily can jump a full percentage point in as little as a few months.   Likewise, there appears to be plenty of raw material in that securitization to push gross defaults well above 9% eventually. For currently, troubled loans (either delinquencies or loans in temporary six-month or one-year grace periods known as forbearance) total 14.05% of the portfolio, or 19.88% of the loans that have reached the repayment stage. The ratio of troubled loans to loans in repayment is above 20% for the next five securitizations issued between October 2004 and March 2006, though the actual default rates haven't had time to build up yet to that of the 2004-1 securitization.   And all this is occurring during an economic recovery that has seen unemployment levels sink to near record levels and real incomes resume their upward march. Debt-encumbered graduates ought to have their pick of satisfactory job opportunities and have no need to apply for six-month forbearances or to not service their loans. And what can explain the behavior of the parents who co-signed so many of the loans?   Perhaps the student-loan repayment problems are a result of the pinch that U.S. households are feeling from carrying record debt loads. Particularly when residential real estate, long the goose laying gold eggs, is now losing value.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Barron's Online: Abbott Labs Pumps Up Its Product Line
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   Abbott Labs caused a flutter among cardiologists at a medical confab March 24 when it said its experimental heart stent may outperform its top-selling rival's.   The medical-products company has jettisoned stodgy businesses in favor of innovative new drugs and medical devices like the Xience V drug-coated stent -- a mesh tube that props open arteries and releases a drug to prevent scarring.   While up 30% in the past year, Abbott Laboratories' (ticker: ABT) stock may not reflect the stent's earnings potential nor that of two cholesterol drugs -- all are expected to hit the market in 2008 -- or growing sales of its blockbuster rheumatoid-arthritis drug, Humira.   The market is catching on. On March 26, Abbott shares jumped 6.3%, their biggest one-day gain since December 2002. Yet some analysts say Abbott's profits could rise as much as 15% annually over the next three years.   Oppenheimer Capital analyst Bryce Hill says "I wouldn't call the stock cheap, but you're paying a reasonable multiple for shares of a company with earnings expectations it will probably beat. If things go well with the new stent, Humira and the new drugs, it's reasonable that the stock could trade at 70 a share."   Last year, pharmaceuticals generated more than half of Abbott's revenues, or $12.4 billion. Nutritional-product sales were $4.3 billion, and diagnostic-test sales exceeded $3.9 billion. Vascular-intervention products provided just 5% of Abbott's business last year. Yet by 2008, vascular-product sales could more than double, according to Prudential Equity Group. And Abbott could control one-third or more of a $3 billion U.S. stent market, now dominated by Boston Scientific and Johnson & Johnson.   "The potential for drug-coated stents present a significant growth opportunity for Abbott," John Capek, head of Abbott's vascular business, told Barron's Online. For years, larger and flashier device and drug makers overshadowed Abbott. But Chief Executive Miles White has shaken things up since Barron's Online wrote about the company three years ago ("Brewing a Turnaround at Abbott Labs," April 1, 2004).   Revenues remain diverse. But under White's watch, low-return businesses have been sold or spun off. And a flurry of deals has opened the door to riskier, but higher-return markets fueled by innovation.   In January, Abbott agreed to sell a chunk of its diagnostics business to General Electric. In 2006, Abbott purchased Kos Pharmaceuticals and its "good"-cholesterol-raising drugs, and snapped up Guidant's stent business, acquiring Xience.   The company says sales should rise 13% to 15% in 2007. Meanwhile, profits should increase 12% in 2007 to $2.81 a share, and climb another 15% in 2008, according to Thomson Financial/Baseline.   "The big story with Abbott is how management has reshaped the company," says Michael Weinstein, an analyst with JPMorgan Securities. "If you look at Abbott's growth drivers over the balance of the decade, they are Humira, acquired when they bought Knoll Pharmaceuticals in 2001, and Xience."   Already Abbott's biggest drug, with revenues topping $2 billion last year, Humira's sales could double by 2008 as the company finds new uses for it. Also in 2008: The cholesterol drugs, Simcor and ABT-335, may debut in the U.S.   For now, Xience V commands the spotlight. Already for sale in Europe and Asia, the final application for the stent, coated with a drug used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients, could reach the Food and Drug Administration next quarter, and the stent could hit the U.S. market in the first half of 2008.   A pivotal study, released March 24 at the American College of Cardiology's annual meeting, found that blockages recurred less frequently in patients treated with a Xience V stent compared with patients treated with Boston Scientific's Taxus, the top-selling U.S. stent. Patients also suffered fewer serious cardiac events, such as heart attacks. Thinner and more flexible than older rivals, Xience V could be easier to implant, causing less damage to blood vessels. Its polymer covering may also be less abrasive.   Still, clinical-trial results could give Abbott an edge at a time when U.S. doctors are using fewer drug-coated stents due to safety concerns, says Bina Mistry, an analyst with Millennium Research Group, a Toronto-based market research firm: "There could be a big shift in market share next year."   JPMorgan's Weinstein expects Xience V sales to hit $1.3 billion by 2009, and contribute 30 cents to profits of $3.71 a share.   Meanwhile, Abbott could launch four more drug-coated stents between 2010 and 2012, including one that dissolves after three years. "With each generation, the technology improves, and the market grows," says Abbott's Capek.   At 19.8 times projected profits for 2007, Abbott changes hands at a 28% premium to the Standard & Poor's 500 and the pharmaceutical sector, according to Thomson Financial.   Yet Abbott's profits in 2007 and 2008 could increase twice as fast as those generated by the index or the pharmaceutical industry. Meanwhile, Abbott's stock trades at a 10% discount to the medical-device industry.   Of course, the stock will suffer if safety fears have a bigger-than-expected impact on the global stent market.   Investors won't tolerate delays or failures getting Xience V through the FDA, or disappointing financial results, especially in Humira sales. But Xience V and Humira could give investors what they want most: robust and accelerating annual profit growth. These days, that's hard to find.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) The Trader: An Orderly Ebb For Stocks
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Webster's defines "risk" as the chance of injury, damage or loss. As the second quarter begins, the stock market is opting for a narrower interpretation: Risk is the prospect of a debilitating economic slowdown -- and the creeping likelihood that persistent inflation could prevent the central bank from swooping in to cut interest rates.   The alarm this risk caused just a month ago has abated somewhat. A recent raft of benign economic data -- and each passing week without a catastrophe from the wobbly land of mortgage loans -- has encouraged the notion that the economy is slowing but still standing. That has helped lift stocks nearly 4% above their March 14 low.   But investors remain wary. Crude oil rose to a seven-month high near $66, and a February uptick in core inflation provided excuses to sell -- whereas a less hesitant market, circa early 2007, might have brushed these aside.   Still, stocks' orderly ebb last week after their mid-March surge smacks more of profit-taking than a serious case of buyers' remorse. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended the week down 127, or 1%, to 12,354. The Standard & Poor's 500 slipped by 15, or 1.1%, to 1421. The Nasdaq Composite Index gave up 27, or 1.1%, to 2422, while the Russell 2000 Index of small stocks fell 9, or 1.1%, to 801.   Each of the major benchmarks ended the month of March higher, and the S&P 500's 1% gain was its ninth rise in 10 months. It also managed a 0.2% rise for the quarter, the seventh gain in eight quarters. Pulse-takers trying to gauge the market's mood found little that is extreme. Until it gets a better grasp of economic risk, the stock market remains in neutral -- just as ready to shift into drive as it is into reverse.   The directional tilt could come as companies report first-quarter earnings. Analysts have ratcheted down their estimates, and profits for S&P 500 companies are projected to improve by just 3.8% -- which, according to Thomson Financial, would produce the smallest quarterly increase since 2002's second quarter.   How companies respond to declining profit growth and weakening margins bears close watching.   Excluding erratic aircraft data, orders for big-ticket items fell in February for a second straight month -- a possible sign corporate belt-tightening may have begun. Will increasing fiscal thrift put a kibosh on hiring -- or worse, lead to job cuts?   So far, the robust job market has been a pillar holding up consumer spending and economic growth. And it's even more crucial now, as tightening credit and declining home prices put in peril America's wealth effect and spending habits.   Over time, debt levels have generally grown with income (the ability to pay debt) and as interest rates declined (the affordability of debt).   So far this decade, nominal gross domestic product has risen at a 5.1% pace, while outstanding credit-market debt is increasing at 8.4%, notes Punk Ziegel analyst Richard Bove. "If the long-term rates were to rise further or incomes grow at slower rates, then it seems highly likely that there would be a rash of defaults throughout the economy," he says.   Given how many money managers and strategists still believe in a "soft landing," any threat to that consensus could still jolt the market enough to produce some injury, damage or loss.     Like a juvenile waistline or a thick head of hair, profit growth is often taken for granted -- until it's gone. But now that economic growth is expected to slow after 14 record quarters of double-digit earnings expansion, will profit growth become a more elusive -- and more coveted -- trait?   Bruce Bartlett, who oversees various growth-equity funds at Lord, Abbett & Co., has been focusing on companies that can deliver conspicuous profit growth driven by good old-fashioned sales increases -- and not just nimble financial engineering and buybacks that nudge up per-share earnings.   Among technology companies, Bartlett believes "gatekeepers" -- those with a product or service others need to expand -- will enjoy keen demand and strong pricing power. One such example is Akamai Technologies (ticker: AKAM), which provides software to help companies distribute, manage and store multimedia content for a world increasingly adept at downloading files and streaming videos.   Based in Cambridge, Mass., the $8 billion company's home turf really is the Internet, given its array of content-delivery services for customers like Apple's (AAPL) iTunes, MySpace and Yahoo! (YHOO).   Revenue climbed 51% last year and is expected to rise more than 40% this year, with few competitors boasting its scope and quality of service. Analysts have roundly raised their estimates to catch up to Akamai's, and Cowen & Co., for one, flags it as an "excellent large-cap play on the growth of multimedia Internet content."   MEMC Electronic Materials (WFR) straddles a similarly choice spot in the semiconductor world. As its ticker symbol suggests, the $14 billion company makes wafers that are the building blocks for microprocessor, memory, logic and other chips. A current polysilicon shortage should at least support, if not drive up, prices of silicon wafers, and the relentless drive for increased memory capacity bodes well for wafer demand. The growing market for solar chips is another reason MEMC margins continue to strengthen.   Meanwhile, some consumer stocks also might better withstand any belt-tightening, since Americans holding off big-ticket splurges may still pay for smaller addictions (and, as always, nothing's too good for the kids). The video-game maker GameStop (GME) targets not just kids, of course -- and a new generation of consoles has game geeks agog, and is fueling another boom.   GameStop last week reported a 38% pop in fourth-quarter earnings, lifted its forecasts and expects same-store sales to grow 12% to 14% this year.   No question, all three stocks are trading near 52-week highs, and none are cheap by conventional price-earnings measures. GameStop was among last week's top gainers, while MEMC was among the first quarter's. "But as we transition to a slower economy, and as profit growth starts to become scarce, stocks that can deliver above-average growth should begin to command a greater premium," Bartlett says.     OmniVision Technologies (OVTI) has made a habit of bucking market trends lately. The maker of image-sensor chips has slipped 61% since May, while other stocks rallied. Since March 22, however, it's jumped 10% as the market has retreated --  egged on by another round of speculation that Eastman Kodak (EK) might buy the Sunnyvale, Calif., company.   Skeptics, short sellers and conspiracy theorists contend that takeover rumors surface whenever OmniVision flubs its earnings, and the company had recently told investors to expect a first-quarter loss. But even without anything sinister at work, OmniVision already faced a bleak picture.   OmniVision makes image-sensor chips used in camera phones, and it competes at the shunned end of an increasingly commodified market. The kind of "CMOS" camera chips that are OmniVision's life blood can also be readily produced by memory-chip makers ("OmniVision's Cloudy Picture," Sept. 18, 2006), and the creeping encroachment by Micron Technology (MU) and Samsung has wrecked OmniVision's pricing power.   Profit margin has begun its slide, and while revenue has held near $135 million over the past three quarters, net income has tumbled from $22 million to $11 million. Analysts are calling for a 44% drop in per-share earnings this year.   Meanwhile, Kodak is no slouch in the imaging department. A 2004 acquisition of National Semiconductor's (NSM) image-sensor business already rounds out Kodak's array of CMOS image sensors for the consumer market. Kodak also has an ongoing agreement with International Business Machines (IBM) to develop and make new image sensors for everything from digital cameras to camera phones.   Citing company policy, a Kodak official declined to comment. An OmniVision spokesman did not return a call Friday afternoon.   Zealous bearish bets -- about 40% of tradable shares are sold short -- mean that short covering can send OmniVision shares momentarily higher. The company also has nearly $6 a share in cash. But R.W. Baird analyst Tristan Gerra expects the cash holding to "continue to erode as management spends in an attempt to reverse course with, however, no expected effect on rapidly deteriorating fundamentals."   Gerra has a price target of 8 on the stock, or 15 times 2008 earnings of 51 cents. Headline: UPDATE:Tata Pwr: To Buy 30% Stake In Bumi Resources' Coal Cos
Story: (Adds details)   NEW DELHI (AP)--India's Tata Power said Saturday it will buy a 30% stake in coal companies owned by Indonesian mining outfit Bumi Resources (BUMI.JK) for $1.1 billion, a move aimed at securing coal supplies for its upcoming power plants.   Tata Power Co. Ltd. (500400.BY), part of India's sprawling business conglomerate Tata group, said in a statement that it has signed an agreement to acquire a coal trading company and 30% stake each in Kaltim Prima Coal and Arutmin Indonesia - all owned by PT Bumi Resources.   The statement described the two coal companies, Kaltim Prima Coal and Arutmin Indonesia, as "world class assets" with "robust financial performance."   This is the second biggest overseas acquisition by the Tata Group, which sealed a deal in January to buy European steel maker Corus Group Plc. for $11.3 billion (CGA).   The Tata Group, with interests ranging from salt to steel and software, is the most aggressive among Indian companies seeking overseas acquisitions to gain global visibility after thriving for decades in a protected home market.   Through acquisitions, Indian companies hope to penetrate new markets, acquire technologies and gain access to raw materials needed for industrialization back home.   "This purchase supports Tata Power's upcoming power projects on the west coast of India," the Tata statement said about the Indonesian acquisition.   The power plants along the west coast, with a total capacity of 7,000 megawatts, will be completed in five year and will require nearly 21 million metric tons of imported coal, the statement said.   Tata Power said it intends to secure the required coal supplies "through a combination of purchasing equity stakes in coal mines as well as entering offtake contracts."   The acquisition comes at a time when coal prices are rising because of a shortage in supplies from some exporting countries.   Kaltim Prima and Arutmin Indonesia are among the world's largest exporting thermal coal producers, the statement said. Together, they produced nearly 53.5 million metric tons of coal in 2006 with more than 95% sold into the export market, it said.   "They have excellent coal export infrastructure and are strategically well placed to act as a source of supply for increasing regional demand."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 03:36 ET (07:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
