Headline: Barron's(4/2) Tech Trader: At Last, Broadcom Looks Ready To Rally
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tiernan Ray   it seems that all the bad news may finally be accounted for at Broadcom. After spending 2006 as a poster child for stock-options excess, the company can now return to the mundane task of making semiconductors for the world's fastest growing markets.   And that may help the stock (ticker: BRCM). Down 30% in the last 12 months and down 4% so far this year, it could soon start to rebound.   Flamboyant founder and former chief executive Henry T. Nicholas III, who gracedbusiness magazines in his Lamborghini in the late '90s, is long gone, having retired in 2003 for "personal reasons."   Which is just as well, given that a Broadcom internal investigation, concluded three months ago, determined that Nicholas was at least partly to blame for backdating of options to the tune of $2.2 billion from 1998 through 2005.   Gone, too, is Chief Financial Officer Bill Ruehle, who, according to Broadcom, may have rigged options grant dates, and who resigned from the company last September, two days before he was to be interviewed about the matter.   The latest  bit of bad news came last Wednesday when Motorola (MOT), one of Broadcom's biggest customers, announced deeply disappointing preliminary sales and profit results  in the March quarter, a fact greeted with a 5% drop in Broadcom shares in the last five days.   With all those awful developments now behind it, Broadcom can welcome incoming CFO Eric K. Brandt with a stunning balance sheet consisting of $2.8 billion of cash and marketable securities, no debt and a cash flow statement that added $721 million last year, faster than in 2005.   In Nicholas' stead is Scott McGregor, formerly a chip executive with Philips Electronics (PHG), the European tech giant. Though he doesn't drive race cars, McGregor managed to increase sales 37% last year, faster than most chip companies, by selling, among other things, the tiny radio chips that wirelessly connect cellphones to so-called Bluetooth headsets.   The recent drama has left Broadcom shares, at a recent 31, trading at a reasonable 21 times 2008's projected earnings, near its lowest multiples of the last two years, even as McGregor leads the company's advance into the fastest-growing market for semiconductors, the cellphone.   "They continue to be very strong in executing plans to enter new chip markets, and they consistently out-engineer many other chip companies," says J.P. Morgan analyst Shawn Webster, commenting on why he initiated coverage of Broadcom in late February with the equivalent of a Buy rating.   Webster estimates the annual market for the kind of semiconductors that Broadcom makes -- including chips that make decisions for networking equipment, chips that decode video in set-top boxes and cellphone chips -- is about $27 billion, seven-and-a-half times Broadcom's sales last year. He expects that market will rise 26% per year on average over the next five years.   Having cleaned house in '06, McGregor can now focus on Broadcom's principle growth market for years to come, namely cellphones, sales of which may rise 10% this year over last year, according to projections from Nokia, the world's biggest phones maker.   Broadcom doesn't yet sell chips to Nokia, and McGregor has acknowledged that it's unacceptable for Broadcom to have all its Bluetooth eggs with one very large customer, meaning Moto.   "We are picking up additional large customers," he told analysts this past October, without naming names. Some analysts have speculated 2007 could see Nokia joining Broadcom's camp.   The expansion in cellphones means 2007 will be a year of higher operating expenses. Broadcom will be investing in making the most advanced chips with the smallest features, on the order of 65 billionths of a meter, or less than one one-hundredth of the width of a human hair.   That's a worthwhile investment, as it will allow Broadcom to do for cellphones what it has done elsewhere: cram more features onto smaller chips that cost less and consume less power. That's just what tomorrow's ultra-slender smart phones need.   To be sure, Broadcom faces substantial entrenched competitors such as Texas Instruments and Qualcomm, which own more than 40% of the market for cellphone chips.   But Broadcom has had good luck of late defending its chip patents, which suggests it's well-armed for the battle. The International Trade Commission is mulling over whether to ban phones using Qualcomm chips from entering the U.S. after Qualcomm was found to infringe on some Broadcom chip patents.   The company's price-earnings multiple for next year is higher than, say, Intel's, at 17 times, but it is far below the 32-times forward earnings at which the stock has peaked during the last two years. Based on that multiple, the stock could have upside to $48 over the next 12 months, some 50% above the current price.   It's possible that the full ramifications of Motorola's bombshell last week could be yet another shoe to drop when Broadcom reveals this quarter's results. But the damage is mitigated because Broadcom's McGregor already lowered analysts' expectations for sales and profit back when he spoke during a conference call in February, and estimates have fallen accordingly.   Worries about Motorola, and about weakness in the chip market more broadly, are of passing concern. But the promise of an exploding market for cellphone chips is where Broadcom, and investors, may do well for some time to come.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Long Live Dead Trees
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   It is hard to find truly out-of-favor assets in the stock, bond, commodity and real-estate markets, because a rising tide of liquidity has swelled values everywhere in recent years. Newsprint, however, is a notable exception, and shares of the two leading North American newsprint producers -- Abitibi-Consolidated and Bowater -- are among the most unloved investments around.   There is good reason Wall Street is cool to Abitibi (ticker: ABY) and Bowater (BOW). U.S. newsprint demand is shrinking because of the ongoing contraction in the newspaper industry. Montreal-based Abitibi and Bowater, of Greenville, S.C., both have lost money since 2002, hurt by interest on their heavy debt burdens.   Bowater shares, at around 23, are down from a 2000 high of 59 and have appreciated little since the company went public at 18 in 1984. There aren't many other companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange with a worse record over the 23-year span -- Dow Jones (DJ), the publisher of Barron's, unfortunately is one of them. Abitibi has been an even greater investment disaster: Its shares languish at $2.80, down from more than 20 a decade ago. Investors regularly ask analysts why they should invest in suppliers to a declining industry.   Those with a little love to spare might be surprised by the bull case for both stocks. As in many depressed industries, it involves consolidation, as well as growing foreign demand. On Jan. 29, the two companies announced merger plans, which, if approved by shareholders and antitrust regulators, will create the third-largest public forest-products company in North America. It will have $8 billion in annual revenue -- behind only Weyerhaeuser (WY) and International Paper (IP) -- and a dominant position in the North American newsprint market, with nearly a 50% market share. In a "merger of equals," Bowater shareholders will get 52% of the combined company, to be called AbitibiBowater, and Abitbi holders will receive 48%.   Both companies have significant production facilities in Canada, as well as mills in the Southeast, where they turn soft woods, primarily pine and spruce trees, into newsprint, lumber, pulp and various paper grades.   The outlook for newsprint is better than many investors perceive because of rising newspaper sales in Eastern Europe, China and India. Newsprint demand actually grew 1% globally last year, despite a 7% drop in North America. Loosening press restrictions and rising wealth are fueling the newspaper boom abroad. The Internet may be the bane of U.S. newspaper publishers, but it is less of a threat in the developing world.   "There's a growing middle class in the developing world that can't afford Internet access at home," says Chip Dillon, forest-products analyst at Citigroup Investment Research. He notes that in China, a middle-class family earning $3,000 a year can afford newspapers but not an Internet connection. Dillon thinks global newsprint demand could rise at a rate of 2% a year by 2008.   Dillon is "positive" on the proposed Abitibi/Bowater merger. "It will enable two relatively leveraged companies to generate a lot of synergies and cost savings," he says. The pair aim to produce $250 million in annual cost savings within two years, a high figure relative to the equity-market values of the two companies. Bowater is valued at $1.4 billion and Abitibi at $1.2 billion. The companies say the present value of those savings is equal to roughly 60% of their combined equity value. Bowater and Abitibi have a combined $5.6 billion of debt.   "Our challenge is to create a low-cost platform and make money out of a declining sector, while funding opportunities in other segments of the forest-products industry and reducing debt," says David Paterson, the chief executive of Bowater. "We felt we needed a bigger footprint to do that."   Paterson thinks the market for many of Bowater's products are "near a cyclical low. With our operating leverage, the math is pretty compelling if we see price or cost improvement. We could quickly delever this company or AbitibiBowater when we see more positive industry trends."   Assuming the merger occurs, both stocks have similar appreciation potential and downside risk. If the deal is blocked by regulators, Bowater probably is the safer choice because it has less debt than Abitibi and is less exposed to the newsprint market. Bowater carries a 3% dividend yield, although it is not covering the dividend from earnings, while Abitibi pays no dividend. It isn't clear now if the merged companies will pay a dividend.   With their large debt loads, Bowater and Abitibi amount to public leveraged buyouts, meaning they offer investors the potential for high returns -- and risks --  that come with LBOs, though without the stiff fees that private-equity firms like Blackstone and Apollo charge their institutional clients. Indeed, several forest-products companies have been taken private in LBOs, including Boise Cascade's wood-products business.   It is a measure of the newsprint industry's disfavor that shares of both Abitibi and Bowater, which popped about 30% on news of the merger, have given up nearly all those gains in the past two months.   Some investors call Abitibi and Bowater "deep value" situations that may require some patience, as both companies could be a year away from profitability. Underscoring the financial challenges, Bowater said last week that its first-quarter results would be poor, with operating income down $15 million to $20 million from fourth-quarter levels.   Dillon cut his first-quarter estimate to a loss of 65 cents a share from a loss of 25 cents a share. The good news is that the first quarter could mark a bottom for Bowater. Dillon expects Bowater to lose more than $1 a share this year but earn $1.30 in 2008, $2.35 in 2009 and possibly $4 in 2010. These estimates exclude merger benefits, which could total $1.50 per Bowater share. Abitibi lost about 35 cents a share from operations in 2006.   Dillon carries a price target of $35 for Bowater and a target of about $5 a share for Abitibi. John Tumazos, an analyst at Prudential Securities, recently lifted his rating on Bowater to Overweight from Neutral and his price target to $39 from $20.   With 30 mills in the U.S. and Canada, Bowater and Abitibi may sell assets if their merger gains antitrust approval. One particularly valuable mill is Bowater's Catawba facility in South Carolina, which has more than 900,000 tons of annual capacity, none of which is newsprint. That mill alone could be worth $1 billion. Abitibi also has significant hydropower assets in Canada that it has started to monetize. The hydro assets also could be worth $1 billion.   Unlike most other commodity producers, U.S. paper and forest-products companies generally have been disappointing investments in recent years. The prospect of corporate break-ups has generated about the only investor excitement in the area, on the theory they will unlock the value of the industry's timber holdings.   The industry probably needs to consolidate further to generate adequate financial returns, and the Abitibi/Bowater merger would be an important step in that direction. Abitibi and Bowater haven't talked about shutting down plants as part of their merger plans, but Tumazos and others think the combined companies will take a hard look at capacity, since North American newsprint demand fell more than 10% in the first quarter and 25% in the past decade.   It has been tough to justify investment in new newsprint facilities given price trends. Prices have fallen to $625 per metric ton from $675 in late 2006. The current quote isn't much higher than the price in the late 1980s.   Abitibi and Bowater are low-cost producers, even compared with the Chinese. The bulk of their production comes from virgin fiber from softwood trees, while most newsprint made outside the U.S comes from recycled newsprint. The fodder for recycled paper comes primarily from the U.S.   One bullish development for Abitibi and Bowater is that the price of old newsprint has nearly doubled to $160 per ton since the fall. This reflects declining supply in the U.S., driven by declining newspaper sales and moves by papers such as The Wall Street Journal to reduce their size. While this is raising costs at Bowater mills that use recycled newsprint, the major cost increases will be felt overseas, particularly in China. The Bush administration also moved Friday to impose new duties on imported coated paper from China -- news that lifted Bowater, Abitibi and other paper stocks.   Analysts expect the Abitibi/Bowater merger to gain Canadian and U.S. antitrust approval, which would allow the deal to close in the third quarter. Because both companies are in the red, regulators are apt to be more lenient. There also has been little opposition from newspaper publishers, as the increased global trade in newsprint makes the companies less powerful. Newsprint will account for about 50% of the new AbitibiBowater's revenue.   Both Abitibi and Bowater are dicey stocks, even at depressed levels. A successful combination is no guarantee of future profitability, but a merger will put the two struggling companies in a stronger competitive and financial position. In view of their operating and financial leverage, Abitibi and Bowater could be profitable if they can cut costs and raise prices. Contrarian investing often pays, and there are few more contrarian plays in the stock market.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Streetwise: Testing The Patience Of Capital
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Torture a spreadsheet long enough and it will tell you anything you want. More than ever, investors are mistreating companies' income statements and balance sheets until they confess to being leveraged-buyout prospects.   This game has been going on for many months, with analysts creating screens sifting for buyout bait based on cash-flow multiples and leverage ratios. Another pastime has been compiling lists of stocks with heavy hedge-fund ownership. All this is meant to sniff out the targets of "impatient capital," those investors with acute incentives to turn a quick buck.   Buyout firms and hedge funds are considered the dominant or default bid in the market, along with companies themselves buying back billions in stock per day. Retail investors are not throwing much money at U.S. stocks and domestic mutual-fund managers are suffering weak flows and holding very little cash.   One small measure of the race to find the next target of a buyout or hedge-fund bull rush is the outperformance this year of mid-cap stocks. The S&P 400 Mid Cap index finished the first quarter up 5.4%, compared to 0.2% for the large-cap S&P 500 and 1.4% for the small-cap Russell 2000. Mid-cap stocks reside in the bullseye valuation range for both buyout artists and hedge funds looking for under-followed but liquid stocks. It's fair to assume plenty of mid-caps have a decent LBO premium built into them by now.   So, if impatient capitalists and their pilot fish have already gotten to so many stocks popping up on those cash-flow and debt-to-capital filters, what's left for patient capital wielders?   How about that humble valuation measure from the pre-Excel, paper-and-pencil era: the price-to-sales ratio?   Morgan Stanley strategist Henry McVey has taken up this retro approach, at the urging of an accomplished value-fund client, and shows a low price-to-sales ratio is a good predictor of future outperformance.   It acts as a proxy for out-of-favor stocks, perhaps ones with cyclically depressed earnings and a fundamental cushion should profit forecasts prove wrong. Sales don't fluctuate as much as earnings or cash flow, and aren't subject to nearly as many aggressive assumptions by CFOs.   McVey points out that in the current market, price-to-sales isn't working to identify leading performers in technology, consumer discretionary and utilities very well (too many investors chasing LBO candidates), but over the past 20 years has worked well in tech, basic materials, healthcare and industrials. Over the long-term, the metric does better than any other widely employed valuation, growth or balance-sheet measure.   A screen of the lowest price-to-sales stocks by sector surfaces a clutch of names worth investigating, with McVey citing Valero Energy (ticker: VLO), U.S. Steel (X), McKesson (MCK) and Unisys (UIS) as favorites. Among those that look expensive by this ratio are UST (UST), Danaher (DHR) and Paychex (PAYX).   Of course, there's nothing wrong with a stock sporting a fairly low price-to-sales ratio that also looks attractive based on free-cash-flow and a sum-of-parts basis. This describes Federated Department Stores (FD), soon to be renamed Macy's.   Federated's purchase of May Department Stores in late 2005 was that rare specimen, a sensible large merger. The deal completed the industry's 100-year process of knitting regional mid-range department stores into national brands. In this case, the better-managed company bought the underperformer, and is now re-branding all stores as Macy's.   At 45.05, Federated shares are trading at less than 90% of sales and 16-times earnings forecasts for this fiscal year, themselves based on modest same-store sales expectations near 3%. Federated management has under-promised and over-delivered on merger-cost savings in the past, and it wouldn't be surprising if they've done so again.   Earnings and free cash flow should ramp further next year as margin enhancements from the May integration take hold. Sales per square foot at longtime Federated stores vastly exceeded those of former May stores. Federated's merchandising and pricing strategies should gradually narrow the gulf. By some bullish estimates, free cash flow per share could double to $4 in two years, which would place the company squarely in those LBO screens, especially considering the significant value of its real estate.   A $4 billion-share buyback was announced Feb. 27, half of it completed instantly, with $2 billion remaining. Encouragingly, analysts' bullishness on Federated has cooled considerably, and yet the stock has held up well.   No doubt, Federated shares will be subject to any periodic fears that arise about a consumer-spending squeeze due to gas prices or housing woes. But Federated doesn't need gaudy sales increases to hit its numbers.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(3/31) Cadbury Plan Attracts Partners; Hershey Mulls Deal
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Julie Jargon in Chicago and Deborah Ball and Jason Singer in London   Potential partners for both Cadbury Schweppes PLC's candy and drinks businesses are lining up quickly, just two weeks after the company said it plans to split in two later this year, according to people familiar with the situation.   The door is open for its candy business to pursue a combination with U.S. rival Hershey Co., in a surprise reversal from 2002 when the charitable trust that controls Hershey blocked a sale of the company at the last minute. LeRoy Zimmerman, chairman of the board of the trust that has 78% of the voting rights for Hershey, said in an interview Friday: "We have a responsibility to listen to all potential possibilities that might come forward." He added, "It's important that the Hershey Trust stay focused on keeping the company competitive and profitable in this global economy."   For his part, Cadbury Chief Executive Officer Todd Stitzer, speaking to analysts in London earlier this week, said a merger with Hershey would make sense because the two companies' businesses are highly complementary.   Hershey has a market capitalization of $12.6 billion. Cadbury's confectionery business is valued at about $17 billion, analysts estimate.   Food companies are feeling pressure to consolidate to gain greater leverage when negotiating with retailers to stock their goods. A combined Hershey-Cadbury brand portfolio, which would include Cadbury's Trident and Dentyne gum as well as Hershey chocolates, would make it easier to persuade supermarkets and convenience stores to provide prime shelf space, such as next to the cash register. For years, there have been fits and starts, but the big wave of deals that was expected by many hasn't happened yet.   Meanwhile, it is looking increasingly likely that Cadbury will sell its drinks business, which includes Dr Pepper, 7 UP and Snapple, to a private-equity buyer. A number of private-equity companies have discussed their interest in the business, which is the No. 3 soft-drinks maker in the U.S., by sales, after Coca-Cola Co. and PepsiCo Inc., people familiar with the matter say. Among others, Lion Capital, Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. are interested, people familiar with the matter said. Blackstone declined to comment and Lion couldn't be reached. KKR declined to comment.   Selling to a rival drinks company would slow down a deal as it would raise antitrust issues and Cadbury isn't likely to break up the drinks business and sell off individual brands, according to people familiar with the situation. Cadbury could also spin off the drinks business as a stand-alone, publicly traded company, an option it laid out two weeks ago.   Cadbury hasn't started a formal auction for its drinks business, and any deal likely won't happen until after June 19, when Cadbury has said it will provide a public update on its breakup plans, people familiar with the matter said. If it goes with private equity, a sale could take place as soon as the late summer, they added.   On the candy side, a combination of Hershey, the largest candy company in the U.S., and Cadbury, the world's biggest candy company by market share, would make sense, analysts and bankers say. The global candy market remains very fragmented, with Cadbury holding only 10%. Hershey is weak in Europe and in the developing markets -- both places where London-based Cadbury is strong. Also, the companies' management teams have a relationship because Hershey distributes Cadbury's chocolate in the U.S.   The Hershey Trust Co., trustee of the Milton Hershey School Trust, hasn't yet had contact with Cadbury, Mr. Zimmerman said. A spokesman for Hershey declined to comment. A spokeswoman for Cadbury also declined to comment.   If he attempts to join with Hershey, it would be the second go-around for Mr. Stitzer, a consummate deal maker who will be CEO of the candy company after the breakup. In 2002, the trust put Hershey on the block and Cadbury teamed up with Nestle SA to jointly bid $10.5 billion before the trust called off the auction.   Since then, Hershey has faced a slowing chocolate market as consumers opt for healthier items. Cadbury's portfolio is heavier in such items as gum and less-fatty hard candies. Hershey's stock is down 18% from its 2005 peak.   When Cadbury bought U.S. brands Trident, Dentyne and Hall's in 2002, it became the only candy company with large shares in chocolate, sugar confectionery and gum. The move has reinvigorated the company, given that sales of gum are rising about twice the rate of chocolate globally.   Any takeover of Hershey could encounter opposition from local communities and politicians in Pennsylvania. In 2002, the potential sale caused an outcry among residents of Hershey, Pa., who worried it would endanger the Milton Hershey School for disadvantaged children, the primary beneficiary of the trust. But, Thursday, Kevin Harley, press secretary for the Pennsylvania attorney general's office, said, "We do not have the ability to intervene in the lawful business decisions of publicly traded companies such as Hershey."   Any bid for Hershey could also prompt a move from Wm. Wrigley Jr. Co., which was poised to win the company in the 2002 auction. A Hershey-Cadbury combination would be bad news for Wrigley. The Chicago company has been trying to expand beyond gum and become a broader confectionery company, similar to the Cadbury model. Wrigley declined to comment.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:00 ET (04:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/2) Deeply In The Black
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Mining is dangerous business, but investors won't have to dig deeply to find the beauty in Walter Industries, a small coal and natural-gas producer based in Tampa, Fla.   Shares of Walter (ticker: WLT), which also has homebuilding and financing operations, have fallen 30% since hitting a 52-week high of 36 last April. Production problems at an Alabama mine pinched coal output last year, letting steam out of the shares. At a recent 25, however, Walter is selling well below the combined value of its parts, which could total as much as $38 a share.   The production problems, including an unstable roof at a deep-shaft mine, have been solved, and Walter is on track to produce up to seven million tons of coal this year. That could help lift profits 17% to $170 million, or $3.06 a share, on revenue of $1.3 billion and it could boost free cash flow to about $82 million.   In the next five years, analysts estimate that Walter can increase earnings per share at a 15% clip, fueled in part by strong demand for the company's main product, metallurgical coal, pricey commodity used mainly in steel production. Walter has up to 20 years of met-coal reserves and is expanding capacity to meet rising demand.   Walter is also pushing to unlock shareholder value by jettisoning its non-coal segments. The company spun off its Mueller Water Products (MWA) unit through an initial public offering in June, and is expected to sell or spin off its financing and home-building operations by 2008, becoming a pure-play coal producer.   "Walter is a good value play," says Robert Van Batenburg, Louis Capital Markets' head of research, "with the potential for one event, such as an accretive acquisition in home building, or a spinoff, to [lead to] a re-rating of the stock."   Van Batenburg thinks Walter is worth 32 a share, almost 11 times his 2007 earnings estimate of $3 a share. But investors currently value the stock at just eight times Wall Street's consensus view of $3.06, well below the price-earnings multiple of 17 afforded coal issues generally.   Walter was founded in 1946 as a home builder, but coal and natural-gas sales generated 52% of last year's $1.3 billion in revenue and more than 90% of operating profit of $270 million. Home building and mortgage generation kicked in 38% of sales.   The financing operation is profitable, and home building, which lost $22 million last year, could show a profit this year; they have good operations and have done lots of cost-cutting. But most fans, like Matt Hagerty of Pennant Capital -- an owner of 2.5 million shares, advocate a breakup, noting that non-core assets mask the value of Walter's coal business. Analysts estimate that Walter could generate Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) of around $300 million this year and $290 million next.   Hagerty estimates that Walter is selling for only four times enterprise value (market value plus net debt) to his '08 estimated Ebitda of $300 million. That's too cheap, he says, for "the best global supply-demand characteristics" in the coal industry. Applying a multiple of six times enterprise value to Ebitda, in line with other coal companies and recent global mining deals, and adding the estimated book value of the home-building and financing operations, Hagerty arrives at a total value of 38 a share -- 52% above the stock's current price.   "These are hard assets trading at 50 cents a share on the dollar," he says. "They need to be put in the right focus for people to digest the story."   Walter's chief financial officer, Joe Troy, says the sluggish housing market will "extend the timeframe" for ditching assets. Meanwhile, capacity expansions at one mine could add two million tons a year, starting in 2009. The company also is eyeing acquisitions.   Walter is small compared with industry giants like Peabody Energy (BTU), which has $5 billion in annual sales. But met-coal has lower levels of impurities (like ash) than regular coal used in boilers to produce steam or electricity.   Met coal commands more than $100 a ton, down from a peak of $120-plus in 2004 but twice the price of regular coal. Walter sells its coal -- mostly to foreign steel makers -- under one-year, fixed-priced contracts that renew in June. It's getting $115 a ton for 2.3 million tons under the current pacts, and is negotiating new agreements now. CFO Troy predicts a settlement in four to six weeks but is mum on price; met-coal producers in Australia and Europe have settled in recent months for more than $95 a ton, leading analysts to estimate Walter will get between $94 and $100 per ton.   Walter's results tend to be volatile, and earnings could slide to $2.71 a share next year. But the company's free cash, expansion plans and 20-cent dividend should keep the fires burning in shareholders' hearts.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ: Dubai Intl Financial Centre Has Held Talks With LSE
Story: (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)       By Alistair MacDonald     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     LONDON (Dow Jones)--The Dubai International Financial Centre has held talks with several financial exchanges, including the London Stock Exchange Group PLC, that could result in it buying a stake in one or more, a person familiar with the matter said.   The exchanges and other institutions, including private equity firms, could also, in turn, buy a stake in Dubai International Financial Centre's Dubai-based stock exchange. Nothing is imminent and most talks have been preliminary, the person said.   Talks with the LSE center mainly around cross listing of stocks on both exchanges, though the option of cross shareholdings has also been raised, another person familiar with the matter said. The LSE has struck agreements with exchanges including the Tokyo Stock Exchange that are likely to lead to cross listings. It continues to talk to others, including recent talks with the JSE Ltd., the operator of South Africa's stock market.   A spokesman for DIFC confirmed that it is talking to about six institutions which are interested in taking a stake in Dubai's exchange, and that the discussions could also involve some cross shareholding. He said that the DIFC isn't contemplating hostile bids for any other party but declined to comment further.   DIFC bought a 3.48% in pan-European exchange operator Euronext NV when it was negotiating with NYSE Group Inc. about being bought by the operator of the New York Stock Exchange.   Stock Exchange operators around the globe have been talking about various combinations for the past year or so. Various factors are adding to the pressure they face to combine or form partnerships such as offering different trading platforms and different financial instruments for investors to trade.     By Alistair MacDonald, The Wall Street Journal     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 10:00 ET (14:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Allegheny Seeks W. Va. Approval For Power Line
Story: CHARLESTON, W.Va. (AP)--Allegheny Energy Inc. (Y) has asked state regulators to approve the West Virginia segment of a proposed 240-mile interstate transmission line.   The Greensburg, Pa.-based company filed an application for the proposed 500-kilovolt line with the Public Service Commission on Friday.   The $1.3 billion Trans-Allegheny Interstate Line, which would be built by Allegheny and Dominion Energy of Richmond, Va., is intended to provide stability for the mid-Atlantic power grid operated by PJM Interconnection and meet increasing demand for electricity.   West Virginia and other states in the region could see blackouts and brownouts as early as 2011 if the line is not built, Allegheny said.   The line would begin in North Strabane Township in Washington County, Pa., then move into Greene County, Pa., before crossing into West Virginia. The line will cross West Virginia and end in Loudoun County, Va.   West Virginia's segment would run about 114 miles through Monongalia, Preston, Tucker, Grant, Hardy and Hampshire counties, Allegheny said.   "We determined our preferred route after careful study, which included the analysis of valuable input we received at public open houses," said David E. Flitman, president of Allegheny Power and Trans-Allegheny Interstate Line Company. "We urge you to stay informed, keep an open mind and support a thorough, fair review of our plans by regulators."   The project is expected to create 700 construction jobs in West Virginia and should be completed in 2011, the utility said.   Allegheny said it plans to ask regulators in Pennsylvania and Virginia in the coming weeks to approve the project.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 31, 2007 11:18 ET (15:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
